Award.AwardTitle: Three Dimensional Radiation GRMHD Simulations of Accretion Flows Around Black Holes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Some of the most luminous objects observed in the universe are associated with black holes accreting near or above the Eddington mass accretion rate. Computer simulations have contributed greatly to our understanding of this accretion, and general relativistic (GR) magneto-hydrodynamic (MHD) codes have been developed and applied widely. However, most methods do not include radiation, and the few that do can handle only limited regimes of optical depth. This project will develop a GR radiation MHD (GRRMHD) code that can handle all optical depths, and use it to study a suite of problems related to luminous accretion disks. The research group already has a radiation module developed for GR hydrodynamics, which they will add into their existing GRMHD code. While that code development is underway, the team will study hydrodynamic disks with radiation and viscosity using their pre-existing methods. Once the new technique is ready, it will be used for work on radiative magnetized disks, focusing on the structure of thin and thick radiation-dominated disks, the role of instabilities in these disks, and the generation of winds and jets by radiative acceleration. The team has some in-house computer capacity for code testing and less demanding computations, but production runs will use NSF's XSEDE supercomputer resources.

This study will improve our understanding of these high-luminosity accretion flows, and even though the work is very technical, the major advances it represents should spark public interest. The results will help to interpret the observational data that has been collected over the years, and will be very valuable for modeling quasar mode feedback in studies of galaxy formation and evolution. The principal researcher has a strong track record in mentoring young scientists, especially women, and will actively seek opportunities to involve more of them in this research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Some of the most luminous objects in astrophysics are accreting black holes. In these systems, gas spirals in towards the black hole, becomes extremely hot, and produces a huge amount of radiation. Understanding the properties of the emitted radiation in these systems is a major area of research, not least because it allows one to study the mysterious object at the center, the black hole.

Theoretical study of black hole accretion is challenging. One must model the motion of gas and magnetic fields in the general relativistic gravitational field of the black hole, while at the same time keeping track of the radiation and its interactions with the gas. The goal of this NSF-supported project was twofold: (1) Develop the first general relativistic magnetohydrodynamics (GRMHD) numerical code that can handle radiation interactions under both transparent and opaque conditions. (2) Carry out multi-dimensional numerical simulations of accreting black holes under a variety of conditions, study the radiation emitted by these systems, and relate the theoretical and numerical results to observations of real objects in the sky.

During the course of the project, the PI and his team developed three numerical codes: (1) KORAL: A GRMHD code which includes radiation under the so-called M1 closure scheme. (2) HEROIC: A radiation post-processing code which converts numerical simulation results from KORAL to spectra and images for comparison with observations. (3) eht-imaging: A software toolkit for analyzing radio and millimeter wave interferometric data to make images.

Using the above codes, a variety of numerical studies were carried out to tackle a number of problems of astrophysical interest. Much of this work was done on NSF-supported supercomputers under the XSEDE program. In addition, a part of the award was used to build a 288-core computer cluster at the PI's home institution, for additional numerical simulations in support of the project.

Over the duration of the award, the PI and members of his group published 49 papers in refereed journals. These papers covered a wide range of topics. The highlight of the work was the application of KORAL, HEROIC and eht-imaging to study the supermassive black hole at the center of the giant elliptical galaxy M87. The image of this black hole, which was publicly released on April 10, 2019, is shown in the attached picture. This image was obtained by analyzing observations carried out by the Event Horizon Telescope (EHT), which is an international consortium of over 200 scientists, including the PI and graduate student Andrew Chael.

The PI and Chael played a significant role in analyzing the EHT observations of M87.  The software package eht-imaging was crucial for converting the measured data to the attached image.  In addition, the codes KORAL and HEROIC were used as part of the supporting theoretical studies carried out by the EHT collaboration for interpretating the image of M87.

During the course of the project, three graduate students advised by the PI completed their PhDs: Yucong Zhu (2015), Xinyi Guo (2018), Andrew Chael (2019). A number of additional students, as well as two postdoctoral fellows, participated in the research and were trained by the PI in computational techniques and theoretical research.
